citation.article-title: Thalassospira lucentensis gen. nov., sp. nov., a new marine member of the alpha-Proteobacteria.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thalassospira lucentensis sp. nov.

Thalassospira lucentensis (lu.cen.ten'sis. M.L. gen. n. from Lucentum, the Latin name in Roman times for Alicante, a coastal town in the south-east of Spain, which is the nearest town to the site from which the isolate was retrieved)

In addition to the traits reported for the genus, the species is able to grow from 4 to 40 °C, is negative for hydrolysis of starch, casein, Tween 80, lecitin, DNA, alginate and agar, and uses the carbon sources shown in Table 1.
Colonies on marine agar are opaque, unpigmented or slighthly yellow, do not swarm, and do not luminesce.
The cellular fatty acid composition includes cycloheptadecanoic acid, and 3-OH hexadecanoic acid is the major hydroxylated fatty acid.
It was isolated from sea water after enrichment in continuous culture and oligotrophic conditions.
It is able to grow in media containing up to 10% NaCl.
